content.description: Climb straight up the slab, passing one left-rising crack along the way (only pro).   Pleasant climbing, only a bit more difficult than Social Disease.
content.protection: A cam. I don't remember what size, but it isn't larger than a #3 C4.
content.location: 6' right of Social Climber and 4' left of a dirty, wet right-facing corner, at the base of the slab.   As with all the routes here, exit climber's left along the top of the slab to regain the BAW path.

content.description: Climb the crack and corner to its top, then climb the easy slab up to the ledge.   Good protection for timid or first-time leaders.
content.protection: Cams to #2 C4s, a few medium stoppers, and one runner to sling a small oak tree.
content.location: This is the obvious cleaned crack and right-facing corner 20' right of the low point of the slab.   Walk off along the slab's top to climber's left.

content.description: This route was established as a training route for beginning leaders. Note that it is not entirely bolted, there are two protectable cracks along the way. One could probably forego them and only clip bolts, but that would entail risk of longer slides in the event of a fall.
content.location: This is the leftmost line of bolts on the slab.

content.description: This route (and its neighbor to the left) was established as a training route for beginning leaders. Note that it is not entirely bolted, there are two protectable cracks along the way. One could probably forego them and only clip bolts, but that would entail risk of longer slides in the event of a fall.
content.location: This is the rightmost line of bolts on the slab.

content.description: Climb on good lumps to the top of the slab. A short "headwall" at the top adds a few more feet of (5.4) climbing if desired, and another, harder (5.7) headwall lies above this.   The climbing is easy, tho currently dirty, and there is no protection.   This is a good never-ever climb, once it gets cleaned up.
content.location: Begin near the lowest point of the slab, just left of center.

content.description: This is a cluster of rock below and slightly east of the Upper Measles Wall, consisting of an 80' low-angled slab, on top of which lies a steep, shorter outcrop. A discontinuous ledge system separates these two formations.   The lower slab makes an excellent first "long" climb, with routes in the 5.0 to 5.3 range. The upper wall is shorter, 20 to 40', with a (impossible?) cave-like overhang on its right flank.
